senses.de: To cause people or things to come together; to assemble or gather.
senses.ex: The conference brought together leading experts from around the world.

Tips.title: Organizing an Event
Tips.description: Use 'bring together' when describing the purpose or outcome of an event, like a conference or meeting.
Tips.example: The workshop aims to bring together community members to discuss local issues.

Tips.title: Combining Elements
Tips.description: Use 'bring together' when talking about combining different things, like ideas, resources, or data.
Tips.example: The report brings together data from multiple sources to provide a comprehensive overview.

senses.de: To reconcile or cause harmony between people.
senses.ex: The mediator tried to bring the two warring families together.

Tips.title: Resolving Conflict
Tips.description: Use 'bring together' when describing efforts to reconcile or create harmony between people who are in disagreement.
Tips.example: Her efforts to bring together the two factions were ultimately successful.

unite.wordDefinition: 'Unite' emphasizes a stronger and more permanent joining than 'bring together', often implying a shared purpose or identity.

assemble.wordDefinition: 'Assemble' focuses on the physical gathering of people or things, while 'bring together' can also refer to a more abstract joining of ideas or concepts.

gather.wordDefinition: 'Gather' is more general and can simply refer to collecting things or people, whereas 'bring together' implies a deliberate act of joining them for a specific reason.
